title: Precision Marksmanship
description: A rifle is useless without the skill to employ it. Precision marksmanship combines fundamental mechanics with field craft—target detection, range estimation, wind reading, and the discipline to execute under pressure. This section builds shooters who can deliver decisive fire at distance.

content.text: The difference between a shooter and a marksman is process. Anyone can get lucky; marksmen create predictable outcomes through disciplined execution. The shot process removes human variables—fatigue, stress, distraction—and replaces them with a mechanical sequence that produces the same result every time. Master this, and the target becomes secondary.
SAMC: The Four Pillars
The shot process consists of four interconnected elements: Stability, Aim, Control, and Movement. Each element must be addressed before, during, and after the shot.

rows: Consistent base of fire, natural point of aim, bone support
Proper eye relief, parallax elimination, hold determination
Smooth press, respiratory pause, mental focus

content.text: Natural Point of Aim

Natural Point of Aim (NPOA) is where your rifle naturally settles when you are relaxed in your shooting position. With proper NPOA, you are behind and directly in line with the rifle, which rests naturally aligned with the target without muscular tension. Test NPOA by dry-firing and cycling the bolt; if your reticle returns to the same point without adjustment, you have achieved NPOA.
Follow Through

Follow through is the forgotten fundamental. Many shooters disengage mentally the moment they press the trigger. Proper follow through means accepting recoil straight back into the shoulder while maintaining sight picture until impact is observed. The reticle should remain on or near the target through the recoil pulse. Do not anticipate recoil; accept it.
Pre-Shot Routine

items: Verify stable position with bone support
Confirm natural point of aim aligns with target
Check parallax and ensure sight picture is clear
Apply safety to fire when ready to engage
Verify round is chambered
Confirm hold determination (elevation and windage)
Begin controlled breathing cycle

content.title: Calling Your Shot
content.text: Always know where your reticle was at the moment of trigger break. This 'shot call' allows you to predict impact location before observing it. If your call matches the observed impact, your system is working. If they differ, investigate the cause before the next shot.

All direct fire engagements begin with detection. The shooter who sees first holds decisive advantage. Detection skills are built on four core fundamentals that transform passive observation into active target acquisition.
Detection Fundamentals

rows: Rapid sequence of techniques to identify potential threats
Determining areas where threats are most likely to appear
Refining initial scan based on environmental irregularities
Determining general location and range for precise engagement

content.text: Detection Indicators

Targets reveal themselves through indicators that contrast with the natural environment. Movement is the most powerful indicator; the human eye detects lateral motion at extreme distances. Shape exposes targets that remain still, with head-and-shoulders silhouettes being particularly distinctive. Shine from optics, exposed skin, or metallic objects catches light unnaturally. Shadow cast by hidden positions often reveals what concealment hides.
Detection Challenges

items: Peripheral targets at the edge of field of view
Camouflaged, masked, or innocuous-appearing targets
Mirage effects from high temperatures and ground heat
Small single targets in complex environments
Urban or jungle terrain with multiple visual layers
Natural and man-made obscurants
Observer fatigue and physical deficiencies

content.text: Detection Best Practices

items: Scan with unaided eye first, then escalate to magnified optics
Understand capabilities and limitations of night vision and thermal
Apply collective search techniques with assigned sectors
Shield eyes from blinding effects of sun
Maintain systematic search pattern without fixating
Periodically return to previously cleared areas

content.text: Optics Employment

Accurate range estimation separates hits from near misses. Three primary factors affect range estimation: nature of the target, nature of the terrain, and light conditions. Error in range translates directly to error in elevation, causing misses above or below the target.
The Mil-Relation Formula
When you know the size of what you are looking at and can measure it through your reticle, mathematics provides range. The formula works in both meters and yards with different constants.

content.title: Mil-Relation Formula
content.text: For meters: Multiply 25.4 by object size in inches to get the constant. Divide by mil reading to get range in meters. For yards: Multiply 27.78 by object size in inches. Divide by mil reading to get range in yards. Before milling, eliminate parallax by adjusting the objective until the target is sharp and the reticle does not shift when you move your head.
Example Calculation
Target is a standing person (72 inches / 1.83 meters). Constant for meters: 25.4 x 72 = 1829. Target measures 2.4 mils in your reticle. Range: 1829 / 2.4 = 762 meters.
Standard Target Sizes
Milling Best Practices

Take caution when milling human targets. For better accuracy, use the mil-relation formula on solid objects of known sizes such as vehicles, building components, or weapons. Height measurements are generally more accurate because a standing person's height is less variable than their apparent width, which changes with body angle.
Environmental Factors

Wind is the marksman's greatest environmental challenge. Gravity is constant and predictable. Wind varies in speed, direction, and effect along the bullet path. Before a mission, teams build appropriate data cards with elevation and wind holds for their weapon system and ammunition.
Wind Value by Direction
Wind Speed Indicators

rows: Wind barely felt, smoke drifts lazily
Leaves rustle, wind felt on exposed skin
Leaves in constant motion, light flags extend
Small branches move, dust and paper raised
Small trees sway, flags fully extended
Large branches move, difficult to walk against
Whole trees in motion, considerable walking resistance

content.text: Reading Mirage

Mirage is visual distortion from heat rising off the ground. Experienced shooters use mirage as a precision wind indicator. Observe mirage through spotting scope at 15-20x magnification. Focus the scope between you and the target, not on the target itself. Mirage will be easy to see on bright sunny days and difficult on overcast days.
Making the Wind Call
Assess wind conditions with three questions: Is it present or not? Is it stable or unstable? Is it predictable or unpredictable? Your confidence in the shot depends on these answers.

items: Present, stable, predictable (4-5 mph constant from 9 o'clock): High hit probability if you read correctly. Skill required: READING.
Present, unstable, predictable (gusting 6-10 mph from 9-10 o'clock): Moderate hit probability if you can time the gusts. Skill required: TIMING.
Present, unstable, unpredictable (changing 5-10 mph, variable direction): Low hit probability. Wait for better conditions or accept risk.

content.text: Target Width in MPH

Using your 1 mph wind value from your ballistic program, you can determine what the width of your target represents in miles per hour at that range. This helps you know how much windage error you can tolerate. Example: At 800 meters, your 1 mph wind value is 0.1 mil. Your target measures 0.57 mils wide. Target width represents 5.7 mph of wind error (0.57 / 0.1 = 5.7).

content.title: Wind at the Muzzle
content.text: Wind conditions near the shooter have more effect on bullet path than wind near the target. The bullet spends more time in the first portion of its flight, and deflection accumulates. Focus wind reading on the first third of the bullet's path.

Not every engagement allows time for deliberate solutions. Fleeting targets and dynamic environments demand rapid engagement techniques. Modern ballistic calculators provide several techniques for quick engagements within defined parameters.
Danger Space Method

Danger Space uses your bullet's trajectory arc to engage targets within a range bracket without adjusting elevation for each specific distance. You dial for the maximum range and hold at the target's beltline. The bullet arc stays within target height across the entire range.

items: Select your gun profile in ballistic calculator
Go to BALLISTICS menu
Set Range to maximum engagement distance (e.g., 500m)
Check MaxO (maximum ordinate). If MaxO does not exceed target height (e.g., 28 inches vs 30 inch target), the method works
Go to RANGE CARD, note elevation for your max range (e.g., 3.9 mils)
Dial this elevation. For any target 100-500m, hold at beltline and fire

content.text: Max Point Blank Range (MPBR)

MPBR establishes a single dial setting that keeps your bullet within a target-sized vital zone from muzzle to maximum effective range. Best for hunting or situations where range estimation time is limited.

items: Select GUN in ballistic calculator
Go to ZR (Zero Range) menu
Select MaxPBR
Change Target Size to 25 inches (average male torso)
Note MPBhld (MPBR hold), e.g., 2.19U mil. Dial this on your turret
MaxPBR shows maximum effective range with this hold
No-go value tells you minimum target size in mils. If target mils greater than No-go, you can use MPBR

content.text: Speed Drop

Speed Drop provides a simplified elevation solution for rapid engagement within specific range brackets. It calculates a single mil value that, when used as a holdover per 100 meters of distance, gives acceptable accuracy.

items: Go to Accuracy 1st menu in ballistic calculator
Select SpdDrp
Select Calculate
Note SpdDrp# value (e.g., 1.3 mil per 100m)
Note Rng Min and Rng Max for effective range of this technique
In the field: Estimate range in hundreds, multiply by speed drop value for holdover

rows: Known area, multiple targets at various ranges
Limited to max ordinate below target height

content.text: The primary shooter depends on the observer for information about target, environmental conditions, and shot observation. Communication must be concise, accurate, and follow a standardized sequence. The cognitive load of precision engagement distributes between team members for better results than either could achieve alone.
Observer Setup

items: Position in line with shooter's gun-target line
Set spotting scope magnification to 15-20x for optimal trace observation and FOV
Focus between shooter and target. Turn focus ring clockwise until target goes clear then fuzzy, then back off until target is sharp
Scan for wind indicators: mirage and vegetation movement
Prepare to observe trace (rising branch, max ordinate, falling branch)

content.text: Trace Observation

Trace is the visible disturbance caused by the bullet in flight. It has three components: rising branch, maximum ordinate, and falling branch. The arc at max ordinate is easiest to see. Trace is visible on cloudy or overcast days and difficult on bright sunny days. Follow the trace on its falling branch into the target. Do not shift focus to the target for results; watch the trace all the way to impact.
Target Indication Dialogue
Observer uses one of the following methods: direct method, reference point method, clock ray method, or pre-made range card. The call moves from general to specific.

rows: FROM BUILDING 4, GO 9 O'CLOCK 10 MILS. ONE MAM, RED SHIRT, BLUE JEANS.
ONE MAM, RED SHIRT, BLUE JEANS, STANDING NEXT TO WHITE HILUX.

content.text: Shot Correction

If the shooter misses, the observer immediately relays a correction based on observed trace and the shooter's call. Use the target's mil dimensions to bound corrections. For elevation miss, use up to the full mil height. For windage miss, use up to the full mil width.

Example: Observer called 0.5 mil left for first shot (target width 0.65 mil). Round missed just off the right side. Add up to the target width to get new wind call: LEFT 1.0 MIL (0.5 original + 0.5 target width).
Subsequent Corrections

content.title: Correction Formula
content.text: Make subsequent corrections using: What is happening now + What shooter called on last shot + What was your last wind call. Corrections state the direction and amount the shooter needs to adjust, not where the round hit.

Hitting targets at distance requires applying correct elevation and windage adjustments to compensate for bullet drop and wind deflection. These adjustments can be dialed onto scope turrets or held in the reticle. Either method requires knowing the correct values from ballistic calculation.
Data On Previous Engagement (DOPE)

The most reliable ballistic data comes from your own rifle, fired under similar conditions, at known distances. A DOPE card documents actual adjustments required for your specific system at various ranges. Empirical data supersedes calculated values because it accounts for all variables specific to your rifle, ammunition, and conditions.
Ballistic Calculator Inputs

When using a ballistic calculator, accuracy depends on input quality. The more accurately you provide muzzle velocity, ballistic coefficient, temperature, altitude, and atmospheric pressure, the more accurate the output.
Spin Drift and Coriolis

At extended ranges (800+ meters), secondary effects become significant. Spin drift causes the bullet to move in the direction of rifling twist (right for right-hand twist). The Coriolis effect causes deflection based on latitude and direction of fire. Modern ballistic calculators account for these effects when enabled.
When extracting 1 mph wind values for your baseline chart, set spin drift to OFF and latitude to 0 to isolate wind effect. Then re-enable these for actual firing solutions.
Loophole Considerations

Shooting through openings introduces mechanical offset concerns. The bullet's path differs from your line of sight due to the scope mounted above the bore. At close distances to the loophole, this offset is significant. With elevation dialed for a distant target, the bore angles upward relative to your sight line. Verify bullet clearance before shooting through any opening.

content.title: Trust Your Rifle
content.text: Calculator output is a starting point. Your rifle is the final authority. When calculator predictions differ from observed impacts, trust what you see. Verify against actual impacts and refine your data accordingly.

The fundamentals of marksmanship are the building blocks upon which all precision shooting rests. Only strict adherence to these fundamentals, shot after shot, removes shooter influence from the outcome. It is not enough to recite them; you must live them during dry fire and live fire.
Prone Position Fundamentals

items: Spine aligned with bore axis to target
Feet separated comfortably, ankles down, toes out for ground contact
Shoulders squared behind stock at approximately 90 degrees
Support hand controls buttstock or bipod for stability
Firing hand grip consistent, trigger finger isolated
Cheek weld consistent for repeatable eye relief

content.text: Trigger Control

Trigger control is the most important fundamental. The trigger must be pressed straight to the rear without disturbing sight alignment. Use the pad of the distal phalanx (first joint to fingertip). Press should be smooth, continuous, and independent of breathing cycle. The shot should surprise you; if you know exactly when it will break, you may be anticipating.
Breathing

Breathing causes the rifle to move. Fire during the natural respiratory pause after exhaling. Do not hold your breath so long that you begin oxygen deprivation. If the shot is not breaking within 3-5 seconds of the respiratory pause, restart the breathing cycle and begin again.
Mental Focus

Precision shooting requires focused attention on the fundamentals, not on the target or the outcome. Focus on what you can control: position, sight picture, trigger press. Let the result happen as a consequence of correct execution. Target fixation and outcome anxiety degrade performance.

items: Clear your mind of distractions and outcome focus
Confirm position stability and natural point of aim
Verify sight picture and hold determination
Begin controlled breathing cycle
Focus attention on front sight or reticle
Begin smooth trigger press during respiratory pause
Accept recoil, maintain sight picture through impact

content.title: Dry Fire
content.text: Dry fire builds fundamentals without the distraction of recoil and noise. A serious shooter dry fires far more than they live fire. The fundamentals practiced in dry fire transfer directly to live fire. Make dry fire a regular part of your training routine.
